body: Relatedly: is there still a need to support python2.4 in the Heron codebase?  I'm now running into some cruft that could just go away if backwards compatibility all the way to 2.4 isn't required.

rebased against https://github.com/twitter/heron/pull/979 again
@sharmaarun Can u also check whether you set a limitation on the vagrant
looks good to me. @billonahill - does this PR looks ok?

@windie This seems a typo when we added the new package namespace for storm compatibility
@sharmaarun is there a more complete error log that we can take look at. Can you try adding --verbose to get a more detailed output of the error.

@lilalinda 
By design, heron-executor spawns children processes and restart them if any failure happens unless the amount of retry exceeds the limitation.

According to the log in stderr:


The stream mgr exited ~ 09:31:46.

According to the log in heron-executor.stdout:

```

```

It seems the heron-executor exited directly without restarting the failed stream mgr.
And I found in the thermos_runner.INFO:

So there was something happened at ~ 09:31:46. It seems mesos sent caught SIGNAL 10 and sent SIGTERM to heron-executor. Heron-executor will then clean (kill, send SIGTERM to all spawned processes). Stream mgr was also killed and printed the stack trace above. So I don't think the death of stream mgr is a result rather than a cause.
So I have questions:
1. Did u run "heron kill ..." to kill the job at ~ 09:31:46 ?
2. What does SIGNAL 10 mean in aurora/mesos?
3. Could u check whether the job hit aurora limitation (for instance, used more ram than required) and was killed by aurora?

Also, currently the stderr & stdout of stream mgr can lose: (https://github.com/twitter/heron/issues/958)
So can u try to change here: https://github.com/twitter/heron/blob/master/heron/executor/src/python/heron-executor.py#L359
to forcibly redirect the logs to a file and share the content of the file with us?

Thanks

In Linux, it means SIGUSR1 as same as POSIX standard.

https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/master/include/uapi/asm-generic/signal.h

Aurora treats this SIGNAL as same as KILL.

https://github.com/apache/aurora/blob/b24619b28c4dbb35188871bacd0091a9e01218e3/src/main/python/apache/thermos/runner/thermos_runner.py#L159

Could we get the log from slave.cpp of aurora? I think it is helpful.

Just clicking around quickly I see a number of pages that still refer to 0.14.0:

http://lucperkins.github.io/heron/docs/getting-started/
http://lucperkins.github.io/heron/docs/developers/topologies/
@kramasamy we should also update the release process to include making this change before tagging the release.

@maosongfu Re your 3 questions:
1. No, I did not run the "heron kill... " command at that time.  I ran it a couple minutes later when the subsequently launched tasks also failed.  The logs you are referring to are the ones from the first task incarnation.
2. @wuye9036 commented on this, I believe.
3. I did not check any Aurora specific logs but you were right: it seems to be a RAM issue!

I followed your guidance and re-built Heron from the latest source code (git `4cbe5ae96b72f`) and it generated a Java Heap out-of-memory error!  The two slave nodes are each configured with 4GB of RAM, and Mesos advertised about 2.7GB available on each.  When I ran the ExclamationTopology out of the box (the code requests 512MB for each of the 2 containers: word and exclaim, so I though it should be around 1GB), and looked at the --verbose output of "heron submit --verbose ..." I saw that Aurora blew it up to 3GB RAM_PER_CONTAINER!

Next, I tried lowering the RAM requested in the source code to 1MB (failed immediately upon "heron submit" asking for a minimum of 192MB) then to 200MB so that it would have a chance to run on my slave nodes.  Then I encountered the Java Heap Space error, which would explain how it failed at different points in the Google Protobuf code (because the out-of-memory gets hit at different times from run to run).

Finally, I bit the bullet and powered everything down (well, just the 2 slaves) and increased the VMs to have 16GB rather than 4GB.  Now things seemed to somewhat work with the code recompiled at the original level of requesting 512MB per container.  I even got some log lines with the bolt counting some emits!  However, the topology still failed and I am running out of time now to debug this further.  I fear I won't get to it until Monday...

Thanks for all your help so far and have a great weekend.  I'll be looking into this further on Monday morning German time.  Best!
